mn120:1.1.comm: This sutta describes a practice by which a mendicant may choose their place of rebirth. This stands in contrast with the normal approach, where a mendicant aims to be free of all rebirth. At MN 16:12.1, a mendicant who practices out of desire for rebirth is said to be bound by an “emotional shackle” (cetasovinibandha). At AN 3.18, the mendicants are said to be horrified by the suggestion that they practice for rebirth as a god, while AN 7.50:9.1 suggests that such aspirations stem from unresolved sexual desire. The present sutta takes a more conciliatory stance, moving from desire for progressively more refined kinds of rebirth to ultimately letting go of rebirth altogether.

mn120:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn120:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn120:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

mn120:2.1.eng: “I shall teach you rebirth by choice.
mn120:2.1.comm: Here saṅkhāra has the same sense “choice” that it has in dependent origination or the five aggregates. In each case, it is the mental volition that is motivated by morally meaningful forces, either greed, hate, and delusion or their opposites, and which creates results according to that moral force. Often this works unconsciously, as the effects of our choices and deeds manifest with or without our comprehension. Here, someone who understands kamma turns it to their advantage by consciously developing an aspiration for a particular desired result. | Upapatti is one of several terms in Pali that regularly mean “rebirth”, such as jāti, (abhi)-nibbatti, okkanti, and punabbhava.

mn120:2.2.pli: taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn120:2.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn120:2.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

mn120:3.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhāya samannāgato hoti, sīlena samannāgato hoti, sutena samannāgato hoti, cāgena samannāgato hoti, paññāya samannāgato hoti.
mn120:3.1.eng: “Take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
mn120:3.1.comm: The aspiration alone is not enough. It only works if the person already has the kammic potential to realize their aims. | In this discourse it is a mendicant who is making the aspiration. The related passages at DN 33:3.1.98 and AN 8.35 focus on “rebirth by giving”, implying the aspirant is a lay person.

mn120:3.3.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā khattiyamahāsālānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
mn120:3.3.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats!’

mn120:3.4.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
mn120:3.4.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.

mn120:3.5.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā ca vihārā ca evaṃ bhāvitā evaṃ bahulīkatā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattanti.
mn120:3.5.eng: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.

mn120:3.6.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattati.
mn120:3.6.eng: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.

mn120:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhāya samannāgato hoti, sīlena samannāgato hoti, sutena samannāgato hoti, cāgena samannāgato hoti, paññāya samannāgato hoti.
mn120:12.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

mn120:12.3.eng: ‘The Divinity of a thousand is long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

mn120:12.4.pli: Sahasso, bhikkhave, brahmā sahassilokadhātuṃ pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn120:12.4.eng: Now the Divinity of a thousand meditates focused on pervading a thousandfold galaxy,
mn120:12.4.comm: The text does not say what “pervading” (pharitvā) means, but presumably it is the “divine meditations” (brahmavihāra), which are said to be “spread” or “pervaded” (eg. MN 7:13.1). See also MN 127:8.2.

mn120:12.5.pli: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā tepi pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn120:12.5.eng: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.

mn120:12.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, cakkhumā puriso ekaṃ āmaṇḍaṃ hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya;
mn120:12.6.eng: As a person with clear eyes might pick up a gallnut in their hand and examine it,

mn120:12.7.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, sahasso brahmā sahassilokadhātuṃ pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn120:12.7.eng: so too the Divinity of a thousand meditates focused on pervading a thousandfold galaxy,

mn120:12.8.pli: Yepi tattha sattā upapannā tepi pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
mn120:12.8.eng: as well as the sentient beings reborn there.

mn120:12.10.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sahassassa brahmuno sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
mn120:12.10.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the Divinity of a thousand!’

mn120:12.11.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
mn120:12.11.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.

mn120:12.12.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā ca vihārā ca evaṃ bhāvitā evaṃ bahulīkatā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattanti.
mn120:12.12.eng: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.
mn120:12.12.comm: This passage raises the question as to how such a reflection leads to rebirth in the Brahmā realms, which requires the development of absorption (eg. AN 4.123). Similar passages take care to specify that in order to be reborn in the Brahmā realm, one must not only be ethical, but “free of desire”, by which they imply the practice of absorption (DN 33:3.1.136 = AN 8.35:4.11). Related passages in Chinese translation relate the development of different levels of absorption to rebirth in the various realms (MA 168 at T i 700c7; Dharmaskandha, T 1537 at T xxvi 506b14), as does the commentary to this sutta. Now, while the current sutta does not mention absorption, it may be considered in light of the meditation practice of the six recollections. One of these is the recollection that the deities, including Brahmās, were reborn due to their faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom—exactly the same qualities mentioned in the present sutta (AN 6.25:6.3). Thus when the present sutta says to “settle on that thought, concentrate on it, and develop it”, the phrase cittaṁ bhāveti implies more than simply “developing the thought” of the aspiration, but means “developing the mind”. In the suttas this implies deep meditation, as for example the case of a teacher of the past, Sunetta, who was “free of desire”; after “developing the mind of love” (mettaṁ cittaṁ bhāvetvā) he was reborn in the Brahmā realm (AN 7.66:13.1). Thus we can interpret the present passage as a way of practicing recollection of the deities, recalling that one’s virtuous qualities are shared with the deities, and developing deep meditation based on the joy that brings.

mn120:12.13.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattati.
mn120:12.13.eng: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.

mn120:32.8.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā viññāṇañcāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.

mn120:32.9.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.

mn120:32.10.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā ca vihārā ca evaṃ bhāvitā evaṃ bahulīkatā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattanti.

mn120:32.11.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattati.

mn120:33-36.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhāya samannāgato hoti, sīlena …

mn120:33-36.6.eng: the gods of the dimension of nothingness …

mn120:33-36.7.eng: the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

mn120:33-36.9.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
mn120:33-36.9.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception!’

mn120:33-36.10.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
mn120:33-36.10.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.

mn120:33-36.11.pli: Tassa te saṅkhārā ca vihārā ca evaṃ bhāvitā evaṃ bahulīkatā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattanti.
mn120:33-36.11.eng: Those choices and meditations of theirs, developed and cultivated like this, lead to rebirth there.

mn120:33-36.12.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo ayaṃ paṭipadā tatrupapattiyā saṃvattati.
mn120:33-36.12.eng: This is the path and the practice that leads to rebirth there.

mn120:37.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhāya samannāgato hoti, sīlena …
mn120:37.1.eng: Furthermore, take a mendicant who has faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom.

mn120:37.6.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyan’ti.
mn120:37.6.eng: ‘If only I might realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

mn120:37.7.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
mn120:37.7.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
mn120:37.7.comm: Just as rebirth in the realms of higher divinity implies the corresponding level of absorption, freedom from rebirth implies the whole eightfold path.

mn120:37.8.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na katthaci upapajjatī”ti.
mn120:37.8.eng: And, mendicants, that mendicant is not reborn anywhere.”

mn120:37.9.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn120:37.10.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn120:37.10.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
